elements.label: De Horis (Book 1)
elements.description: In Latin. A nineteenth-century reprint (by the indefatigable Nathaniel Darcy-Evers) of a fourteenth-century Latin translation of a fourth-century work.

elements.label: De Horis (Book 2)
elements.description: In Latin. A nineteenth-century reprint (by the indefatigable Nathaniel Darcy-Evers) of a fourteenth-century Latin translation of a fourth-century work.

elements.label: De Bellis Murorum
elements.description: In Latin. An eighteenth-century epic poem by the pseudonymous 'Solipsistos'.

elements.label: On What Is Contained By Silver
elements.description: A bestiary by 'Poemander'. In Greek.

elements.label: A True and Complete Accounting of the Asclepian Mysteries of the Roots of the House
elements.description: Reproduced by one 'Rylee Grese' from - supposedly - a much older text. In Greek.

elements.label: The Orchid Transfigurations, Vol 1
elements.description: A sixteenth-century alchemical fever-dream, attributed to Robert Fludd, frequently banned for the disturbing allure of its illustrations. This is in the original Latin.

elements.label: The Orchid Transfigurations, Vol 2
elements.description: A sixteenth-century alchemical fever-dream, attributed to Robert Fludd, frequently banned for the disturbing allure of its illustrations. This is in the original Latin.

elements.label: The Orchid Transfigurations, Vol 3
elements.description: A sixteenth-century alchemical fever-dream, attributed to Robert Fludd, frequently banned for the disturbing allure of its illustrations. This is in the original Latin.

elements.label: The Geminiad
elements.description: A fragile manuscript, illuminated with twinned shapes of sad and luminous beauty, and with all the phases of the moon. It might be as old as the seventh century, but the language - Fucine - is much older. Coral decorates its cover, and its page-edges are sharp enough to slash a throat.

elements.label: The Ciphered Journal of Alessandro LaCroce
elements.description: Prince Alessandro LaCroce spent years in secret study of the tablets taken from the Fucine Marshes in central Italy. His work will allow you to read Fucine texts... but it's written in a simple Latin cipher. You'll need to decipher it first.

elements.label: The Velshorn Inscriptions
elements.description: Hundreds of matching lines in Greek and Phrygian poetry, copied from a wall. Similar - or identical - to the inscriptions Cal Velshorn discovered in Halicarnassus. [If you speak Greek, you can use this as a key to Phrygian.]

elements.label: The August Stone
elements.description: A tremendous bowl, big as a gong, carved from black basalt, with matching incantations in Aramaic and Mandaic. [If you speak Aramaic, you can use this as a key to Mandaic.]

elements.label: An Enigmatic Sculpture
elements.description: An elaborate ivory sculpture of impossible intricacy. Around and across its surfaces, Sanskrit inscriptions spiral against matching lines of Vak. [If you speak Sanskrit, you can use this to learn Vak, the first language of the world.]

elements.label: The Irreproachable Traditions...
elements.description: The Irreproachable Traditions of the Society of the Noble Endeavour. In Latin.

elements.label: The Rose of Nuriel
elements.description: Marked with the tripled sign of the arcane-contemplative order known as the Sisterhood of the Knot. In Greek.

elements.label: The Rose of Hypatia
elements.description: Marked with the tripled sign of the arcane-contemplative order known as the Sisterhood of the Knot. In Greek.

elements.label: The Rose of Waznei
elements.description: Marked with the tripled sign of the arcane-contemplative order known as the Sisterhood of the Knot... but a fourth leaf has been added, disfiguring the sign. In Greek.

elements.label: Sunset Passages
elements.description: A holy text of the Church of the Unconquered Sun, which in many histories was driven underground. In Latin.

elements.label: The Gospel of Zacchaeus
elements.description: A lost early Christian text? It's in Greek.

elements.label: On Matthias and the Amethyst Imago: Loss
elements.description: The diagrams and illustrations, even across the centuries, are elegant, hypnotic, occasionally erotic. In Aramaic.

elements.label: On Matthias and the Amethyst Imago: Transformation
elements.description: The diagrams and illustrations, even across the centuries, are elegant, hypnotic, occasionally erotic. In Aramaic.

elements.label: On Matthias and the Amethyst Imago: Pursuit
elements.description: The diagrams and illustrations, even across the centuries, are elegant, hypnotic, occasionally erotic. In Aramaic.

elements.label: Lord Franklin Bancroft: Diaries, 1750-1790
elements.description: The notorious journal of a notorious gentleman, written in Latin, no doubt for the sake of safety.

elements.label: Those Indignities Perpetrated By the Deceitful Fraternity of Obliviates
elements.description: This book is as famous for the near-incoherent fury of its tone, as for the knowledge it contains. In Latin.

elements.label: The Furious Tantra
elements.description: As later transcribed by the medium and pyrotechnician Jacob Oliver Topp-Mugglestone. Tradition has it that he found it seared in the bark of an oak by lightning.

elements.label: The Devoured Tantra
elements.description: The diplomat-priest Stanislav John Schaller transcribed this from the library of a Red Long, but his manuscript remains in a private collection in Kerisham.

elements.label: The Ceaseless Tantra
elements.description: The avant-garde choreographer Nicholas Keirle supposedly incorporated this tantra into his menacing ballets.

elements.label: The Known-Unknown Tantra
elements.description: Carlos Garcia Sauri, the ecstatic mystic of the Pyrenees, was known to recite this in three languages, though he had never visited the Subcontinent.

elements.label: The Encircling Tantra
elements.description: The explorer and entrepreneur T. Everett Duplantis once attempted to plunder the temple where this text was held. His fate is recorded in an appendix.

elements.label: The Shaven Lock Tantra
elements.description: Also known as 'The One Who Has Shaven His Hair'. This, the story goes, is the lore that even the shapechanging Vanaras rejected.

elements.label: The Tantra of Worms
elements.description: The entomologist Juliana Zawistowski eventually came to insist that this text was written by insects inhabiting a human skin. She never presented evidence for her claim.

elements.label: The Book of the Centipede
elements.description: In the mid 1860s one 'Madam Yi' presented an entertainment based, she claimed, on this book.

elements.label: The Account of Kanishk at the Spider's Door
elements.description: Lok Kahuli, Kanishk's victim and lover, wrote this account, perhaps posthumously.

elements.label: The Vinzant Inscriptions
elements.description: Everett Vinzant transcribed these Phrygian incriptions from a cliff in Anatolia, where he famously survived a lightning-strike. He died seven years later to the day. His bones, the legend has it, were hot to the touch.

elements.label: The Larquebine Codex
elements.description: Christoph Larquebus claimed to have purchased two hand-written copies of the Codex, in the supposedly-extinct Phrygian tongue, from a family of witches on the shores of the Sea of Marmara. A third was 'given to the Sea'.

elements.label: Against the Sisterhood of the Knot and...
elements.description: 'Against the Sisterhood of the Knot and the Foulness of their Depraved Customs'. Hieronymus Pseudo-Hypnerotomachus wrote this furious screed about the sinister influence of the Sisterhood on his own Church of the Unconquered Sun.

elements.label: The Morphy Codex
elements.description: A text of the Sisterhood of the Knot, unearthed by Evan Morphy.

elements.label: The Leonine Tantra
elements.description: In the most notorious translation of the Leonine Tantra, Ashley Phillips is listed as the translator, but their existence is explicitly denied in the prologue. This confusion is characteristic of books which mention the Great Hooded Princes.

elements.label: The Incandescent Tantra
elements.description: Michael Blockley, the eccentric iron magnate, was fond of quoting from this tantra. Blockley died in a factory fire.

elements.label: The Thirsting Tantra
elements.description: C.G. Burial, the temperance campaigner, published elements of this in a pamphlet, which had to be withdrawn and destroyed after it became too popular.

elements.label: The Flayed Tantra
elements.description: This Tantra is recorded as being spoken by an enigmatic individual identified as 'Peel', with many of the qualities of the mythological naga. The Flayed Tantra played a notable part in Alexander Sparrow's paranoid pamphleteering.

elements.label: The Watchful Tantra
elements.description: Notorious for its involvement in the deaths of Dafyd Jones and Meredith Blaine, two early physicists who each claimed to have the only copy and who ultimately fought a duel over it in 1840.

elements.label: The Twin-Serpent Tantra
elements.description: A tantra shrouded in particular obscurity.

elements.label: The Fire-Circle Tantra
elements.description: The one known extant copy of this in Western Europe was stolen from the British Library in 1892. One Harvey Hattington confessed to the crime and claimed to have eaten it, with butter and garlic, in a moment of ungovernable whimsy.

elements.label: As The Sun His Course
elements.description: Joel of the Bridge, a retired soldier and sometime tollkeeper, wrote this epic poem about Alexander's famously inexplicable decision at Issus to withdraw from the war with the Achaemenids, and his subsequent return to Macedonia.

elements.label: The Concursum Diaries
elements.description: The diaries of the explorer and murderer Lars Westergren. He's unhelpfully translated them into Phrygian, for privacy.

elements.label: The Iron Book
elements.description: A manual of the Ordo Limiae, an order of quasi-immortals who maintained a secret enclave at the source of the river Limia, in the Roman province of Hispania Gallaecia.

elements.label: The Silver Book
elements.description: A manual of the Ordo Limiae, an order of quasi-immortals who maintained a secret enclave at the source of the river Limia, in the Roman province of Hispania Gallaecia.

elements.label: The Ivory Book
elements.description: A manual of the Ordo Limiae, an order of quasi-immortals who maintained a secret enclave at the source of the river Limia, in the Roman province of Hispania Gallaecia.

elements.label: The World Does Not Weep
elements.description: 'Brown' Joshua found this in a well in Hamath. There's an unlikely story that it was abandoned by Alexander during his retreat from Issus.

elements.label: The Deeds of the Scarred Captain
elements.description: Painstakingly assembled by the soldier of fortune and sometime remittance man, Pavel Shulga, during his years in Greece.

elements.label: The Book of Dissolution
elements.description: Alexander Probst, following the foundational work of Hosty Moor, recovered a copy of this work from a mountain-temple in Persia. Other copies surface now and then, usually seared on rock.

elements.label: A Catalogue of Uncharted Pleasures
elements.description: 'The Dark Gentleman' is the only, and rather grandiosely, identified author of this often-copied work.

elements.label: Those Who Do Not Sleep
elements.description: A Fucine text attributed to the mystic, Brodnax.

elements.label: The Sky, the Soul
elements.description: The grand labour of Kalle, an ascetic poet writing at the court of the Shadowless Kings.

elements.label: On the Matter and the Deeds of Serpents
elements.description: This was probably the 'Prophecies of the Naga' rendered into English, and illustrated, by 'William Midnight' in Paris in the 1880s; but it shows a number of divergences from that text. It's certainly quite recent by the standards of Vak texts.

elements.label: The Serenity of the Black Wood
elements.description: An allegorical history of the House of Lethe, who it is here implied were inspired by the Centipede. 'Sereno Blackwood' is an occult alias to this day.

elements.label: The Book of Thrones
elements.description: A legend of the Shadowless Empire, transcribed by Alexander Peterhans from annals at a secret shrine in Anatolia.

elements.label: A Second Glory
elements.description: A work by Juceh, the priest and hermit scholar.

elements.label: Book of True Blood
elements.description: A work by Cassius the Thoman.

elements.label: The Burning Woman
elements.description: A transcription of the play by Menander the Victor, possibly the dramatist of that name, into Phrygian, with commentaries.

elements.label: Twenty-Six Enticements, Seven Torments
elements.description: The painter Niels Frederik Malsk√¶r, notoriously, attempted a series of paintings based on the Torments. By the Fifth Torment, the demands of the painting had grown so dire that he died of blood loss. The diagrams in this text are thankfully less detailed.

elements.label: A True and Accurate History of the Shadowless Kings
elements.description: Isaac of Karth's history of the Shadowless Empire.

elements.label: The High Mysteries of the Innermost...
elements.description: 'The High Mysteries of the Innermost Chamber of our Church Solar'. Secret rites of the Church of the Unconquered Sun, which held power in at least two Histories.

elements.label: Medusa's Lament
elements.description: On the death of the Hour called Seven-Coils, 'the Father of the Mother'.

elements.label: The Book of Masks
elements.description: Athena Vana's work on the rogue Hour called the Vagabond.

elements.label: In The Mountains As Upon The Plain...
elements.description: 'In The Mountains As Upon The Plain There May Not Be A Path Where None Has Passed.' A work by Ninegala of Lagash.

elements.label: In Memory of Gods
elements.description: A work by 'the Barrowchild', a nameless Gaulish adept who joined an organisation known as the Ordo Limiae.

elements.label: The Sevenfold Slaying of the Seven-Coiled
elements.description: An account of the destruction of a primaeval Hour, a god-who-was-Stone.

elements.label: My Deeds, My Powers, My Achievements...
elements.description: 'My Deeds, My Powers, My Achievements and the Injustices Perpetrated Against Me'

elements.label: The Dream of the Conspiracy of the Lower Skies
elements.description: Siftings of the disgraced oracle Damaon Azenaten.

elements.label: The Book of the White Cat
elements.description: Stories brought to Penelope of Gordion by a blind white cat.

elements.label: The Focus of Amber
elements.description: The penance-work of Omar, the Blaze.

elements.label: The Songs of the Carapace Cross
elements.description: Micah Xi's often-destroyed work.

elements.label: The Origins of Hours
elements.description: A Vak work that may contain gossip about the various origins of the secret gods.

elements.label: Where Has She Gone?
elements.description: A discussion in Vak of the Vagabond's travels.

elements.label: The Book of the Extinguished Heart
elements.description: A book of melancholy prophecy.

elements.label: How the End will Begin
elements.description: A book of bleak prophecy.

elements.label: The Manner in which the Alchemist was Spared
elements.description: A quasi-alchemical text, in Vak.

elements.label: Five Creations
elements.description: The itinerant scholar Shohei debated five possible origins for humanity with a hooded figure since claimed to be the Beach-Crow. Shohei later claimed that all these accounts had proven false, but the debate was, nevertheless, recorded.

elements.label: Commandments For the Preservation...
elements.description: 'Commandments For the Preservation of All That Exists'. Black Elie, Damascene Matriarch of the Sisterhood of the Knot, was imprisoned by the emperor Didius Julianus. She reportedly instructed that these secret doctrines be recorded in writing to preserve against their loss. Regrettably, the story goes, Didius Julianus ordered that the work be entombed with her in an unmarked sepulcher.

elements.label: The Time of Division
elements.description: In which Amira Zahra prophesies the events later known as the Intercalate, when the Hour called Sun-in-Splendour will be divided.

elements.label: A Manual for Departure
elements.description: The author, who identifies itself as the Jekadu, claims to be one of the Great Hooded Princes of the Land of the River.

elements.label: Inaam, Kapigiginlupir, Garkie, Cryppys
elements.description: In which four enigmatic figures tell the stories they've heard over the years at the Roost, the secret location where the aviform Hours congregate.

elements.label: The Voyages of Ferninshun of Oreol
elements.description: The impossible travels of a sea-captain of the late Phoenician era. Suppressed throughout recorded history: those who read it were said to disappear.

elements.label: The Scar in the Sky
elements.description: Nyn wrote this, and came to regret it.
